prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Disk Kinematics
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observe C18O, 13CO, 13CS, and SO toward protostellar disk candidates in Perseus.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We have configured to correlator for high spectral resolution observations of C18O (J=2-1), 13CO (J=2-1), SO (6-5), c-C3H2, 13CS (J=6-5), and CO (J=2-1). A velocity resolution of 0.1 km/s is optimal for characterizing the rotation curves of these protostellar disks which may have line widths between 2 - 4 km/s due rotation. The high spectral resolution is necessary because the lines emission will also have positional shifts with relatively small velocity changes; the change in position with velocity is the essential feature enabling us to map the rotation curve.
C18O and c-C3H2 are in baseband 1, 13CO and SO are in baseband 2, CO and 13CS are in baseband 3, and baseband 4 is allocated to low resolution continuum. All spectral line observations use spectral averaging of 2 to lower the data rate because the difference between no spectral averaging and 2 is only ~0.01 km/s. CO uses a spectral averaging of 8, getting 0.3 km/s resolution, this is acceptable for this line because it is expected to trace higher velocity outflow emission with even broader line width. The narrowest bandwidths are chosed for the spectral line observations because the lines are only 2-4 km/s (up to +/- 20 for 12CO) and the lines will fit entirely within these bands. With the configured spectral resolution, our lines will have at least 10 resolution elements and be well-resolved.

We require 0.2" resolution in order to resolve the kinematic structure of the protostellar disks on scales comparable to the size of the 8 mm dust continuum images. Assuming signal-to-noise of 5 at the highest velocities (emission origination from the smallest scales in Keperlain rotation), we will be able to centroid the emisison down to ~0.04" (10 AU) accuracy (beam/signal-to-noise), enabling us to map the rotation curves from the outer disk into the inner disk. The largest angular scale of 3.4" is necessary to sample continuum emission from the full extent of the Keplerian disks around these protostars, the largest of which is ~ 2". Moreover, 3" angular scale will enable us to examine emission coming from the inner envelopes, in addition to the Keplerian disks and possibly determine the transition from the infalling envelope to the disk.
The declination of Perseus is about 31 degrees (max. elevation 36 degrees), casuing the beam to be elongated in the north-south direction yielding 0.35" X 0.2" resolution; the 0.15" elongation will not affect our ability to map the rotation curves in these sources.

The sensitivity of these observations is driven by the need to detect C18O emission on the scales of the disks toward the protostellar sources. To determine our necessary sensitivity, we have examined the C18O emission from the confirmed Keplerian disk around VLA1623. Scaling the flux densities observed toward to the distance of Perseus (~230 pc), VLA1623 has a C18O (J=2-1) line flux density of 59 mJy/beam at 2 km/s from line center. The emission is point-like at these velocities, so the signal-to-noise regime is that of a point source. Therefore, to gain a signal to noise of at least 5 in the high-velocity wings toward a Class 0 source similar to VLA 1623, we need a sensivitiy of 11.8 mJy/beam. This will enable us to centroid emission on scales down to $\sim$10 AU. The line emission at velocities less than +/- 2 km/s will also be brighter so, signal-to-noise of 5 is the minumum.
The continuum sensitivity reached in the observations will easily detect all the sources in the proposed observations. All sources have previous lower resolution detections at 1.3 mm with CARMA and the SMA (0.3" - 1.0" some published in Tobin et al. 2015, Hull et al. 2014, and some from the SMA MASSES survey (Dunham et al. in prep.). The faintest proposed source will be detected with a signal to noise well over 100 in the continuum.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Disks play a pivotal role in the formation of stars and planets. Nevertheless, disks are poorly characterized in the earliest phase of the star formation process (i.e., the Class 0 phase). We propose ALMA observations of molecular lines (e.g., C18O J=2-1) toward twelve new protostellar disk candidates discovered in an unbiased VLA 8 mm survey of all known protostars in the Perseus cloud (d=230 pc). The molecular line observations will enable us to determine if the resolved, disk-like structures at 8 mm have kinematics consistent with rotational support. These observations are essential to the interpretation of our VLA continuum data. We cannot fully understand the nature of these resolved structures without knowledge of their kinematics. The proposed sample has the potential to double the number of Keplerian Class 0 protostellar disks and protostellar masses known early in the star formation process and broaden our knowledge of Class I protostar masses. Thus, these observations have the potential to significantly broaden our evolving understanding of disks in the protostellar phase and the rate of protostellar mass build-up.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: 2015,1.00061.S, 'Chemistry Unveils the Physics of Embedded Disks', PI John Tobin 2015.1.00316.S, 'Are Close Binaries Formed Through Disk Fragmentation?', PI John Tobin 2015,1,00xxx.S,'Detection of a Fragmenting Class 0 Disk', PI Mike Dunham
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2013.1.00031.S, 'Are Close Binaries Formed through Disk Fragmentation?', PI: John Tobin 2013.1.00209.S, ' The Stellar Masses and Disk Properties of Class I Protostars: Edge-on Disks in Orion', PI: John Tobin 2012.1.01069.S,'Mapping the Envelopes of Edge-On Orion Protostars', PI: Will Fischer
